title: Kill-or-be-killed threat
vignette: An assailant tells Alex: “If you don’t shoot Sam, I’ll shoot you right now.”

options.text: Refuse and face death rather than take Sam’s life.
Comply and kill Sam to save yourself.

title: Surrendering one life to save many
vignette: Armed kidnappers seize a tour group and demand: “Choose one person for us to kill, or we kill you all.”

options.text: Refuse to hand anyone over, even if it means everyone may die.
Select one person so the rest can live.

title: Stopping a violent attacker
vignette: You see someone chasing a victim with intent to murder or rape. May by-standers use deadly force to stop the attacker?

options.text: Yes, lethal force is immediately permitted to protect the victim.
Try non-lethal methods first; kill only if nothing else works.

title: Night-time burglar break-in
vignette: At midnight a homeowner hears someone tunnelling into the house. May the owner shoot the intruder before seeing a weapon?

options.text: Yes; assume the burglar would kill if confronted.
No; lethal self-defence is justified only when a clear mortal threat is present.

title: Foetus endangering the mother
vignette: During a difficult birth the baby’s position threatens the mother’s life. May doctors dismember the foetus to save her?

options.text: Yes; treat the foetus as the source of danger and save the mother.
No; do not kill the foetus even to save the mother.

title: Love-sick patient request
vignette: A man becomes critically ill from obsessive desire for one woman. Physicians say only sexual contact (or even seeing her naked) will cure him.

options.text: Permit the contact to save his life.
Refuse; better he die than violate sexual boundaries.

title: Vigilante killing of public offenders
vignette: In a public square a local and a foreigner are caught having prohibited intercourse. May zealots kill them on the spot without trial?

options.text: Yes, but only if they act instantly and without consulting a court.
No; killing without due process is murder.

title: Rescuing someone in danger at personal risk
vignette: You see a stranger drowning or being mauled. Are you obligated to jump in even if it puts you in moderate danger?

options.text: Yes; you must risk yourself within reason to rescue.
No; you are not required to endanger your own life.

title: Executing a dangerous minor
vignette: A teenage boy is compulsively violent and experts say he will one day become a murderer. Should the court execute him now to prevent future killings?

options.text: Yes; pre-emptive execution is justified.
No; never impose the death penalty for crimes not yet committed.

title: Destroying a city for mass idolatry
vignette: An entire town turns to idol worship. Must authorities execute all residents and burn the property?

options.text: Yes; collective punishment is mandatory for such apostasy.
No; total destruction is immoral or should never be applied.

title: Capital penalty for a rebel scholar
vignette: A famous professor publicly defies the supreme court’s ruling on a legal matter. Should he be put to death to maintain legal unity?

options.text: Yes; harsh punishment deters challenges to the court.
No; killing dissenters is unjustified.

title: How often should courts execute?
vignette: Some judges say a court that executes a person even once in 70 years is too blood-thirsty; others say frequent executions deter crime. Which view is better?

options.text: Rare or never—capital punishment should be almost unheard of.
Use it whenever legally warranted to protect society.

title: Confession in death-penalty trials
vignette: A defendant on trial for murder confesses in court. May the confession be used to convict (or acquit) him?

options.text: Confession cannot be used to convict in a capital case.
Accept the confession; people own their words.

title: Punishment for false witnesses
vignette: Two witnesses fabricate testimony that could have led to an innocent person’s execution but are exposed just in time. Should they receive the same death penalty they intended?

options.text: Yes; give them the penalty they tried to impose.
No; intent alone shouldn’t carry a death sentence.

title: Idolatry under threat of death
vignette: A tyrant orders: “Bow to this idol or I will kill you.” Must the victim choose death rather than worship?

options.text: Die rather than commit idolatry.
Pretend to worship to stay alive.

title: Sexual sin under threat
vignette: An oppressor says: “Have forbidden sex with this person or be killed.” Must one die rather than comply?

options.text: Choose death rather than commit the act.
Commit the act to preserve your life.

title: Minor rule under coercion—public vs. private
vignette: Guards threaten to kill a Jew unless he privately wears a fabric forbidden by his religion. Would the ruling change if they force him to do it publicly before a crowd?

options.text: May comply in private but must resist in public to avoid public desecration.
Resist even in private; never break the rule under threat.

title: Paying others to rescue
vignette: You can’t personally reach a child trapped under rubble, but professional rescuers will come for a fee. Are you obliged to spend your own money?

options.text: Yes; must pay what’s needed to enable the rescue.
No; moral duty ends with personal effort, not monetary loss.
